case_id: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar (2014)
facts: Appellant Arnesh Kumar and Respondent were married on an unspecified date.

Respondent filed a complaint alleging offences punishable under Section 498A of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and Sections 3 and 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act against the appellant and his family members.
The appellant was arrested based on the said complaint.
The appellant applied for bail, which was rejected by the lower courts.
The appellant filed a petition before the Supreme Court seeking bail and challenging the automatic arrest in cases registered under Section 498A IPC.

prosecution_arguments.argument: Sufficient grounds existed to suspect the appellant of committing offences under Section 498A IPC.
precedents: State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal, 1992 Supp (1) SCC 335: Police have the power to investigate cognizable offenses.
Joginder Kumar v. State of U.P., (1994) 4 SCC 260: Arrest is a part of the investigation process.
D.K. Basu v. State of W.B., (1997) 1 SCC 416: Guidelines for arrest to prevent its abuse.
elements: Cruelty towards a woman by her husband or his relatives.
The cruelty must be of such a nature as is likely to drive the woman to commit suicide or to cause grave injury or danger to life, limb or health (whether mental or physical) of the woman; or

Harassment of the woman where such harassment is with a view to coercing her or any person related to her to meet any unlawful demand for any property or valuable security or is on account of failure by her or any person related to her to meet such demand.

counter_arguments.loophole: The complaint may be false and motivated by ulterior motives, such as matrimonial discord.
supporting_precedents: Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand, (2010) 7 SCC 667: Courts must be cautious in dealing with 498A cases due to their misuse.
Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, (2014) 8 SCC 273: Directions to prevent automatic arrests in 498A cases.
Social Action Forum for Manav Adhikar and Another v. Union of India, (2018) 10 SCC 443: Discussing the misuse of Section 498A.

defense_arguments.argument: The arrest was illegal and unjustified due to the lack of reasonable belief that the appellant had committed the alleged offense.
edge_cases: The case involves matrimonial disputes, and the allegations are vague and unsubstantiated.
The police failed to follow the guidelines laid down in Section 41 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) before making the arrest.
precedents: Joginder Kumar v. State of U.P., (1994) 4 SCC 260: Emphasized the importance of not making arrests routinely.
D.K. Basu v. State of W.B., (1997) 1 SCC 416: Laid down specific guidelines for arrest to prevent its abuse.
Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, (2014) 8 SCC 273: Issued directions to prevent automatic arrests in 498A cases.

defense_arguments.argument: The allegations under Section 498A are fabricated and intended to harass the appellant and his family.
edge_cases: The case is filed as a counterblast to divorce proceedings or other matrimonial disputes.
There is no independent corroboration of the allegations made by the complainant.
precedents: Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand, (2010) 7 SCC 667: Cautioned against the misuse of Section 498A in matrimonial disputes.
Rajesh Sharma v. State of U.P., (2018) 10 SCC 472: Issued directions to prevent the misuse of Section 498A.
Social Action Forum for Manav Adhikar and Another v. Union of India, (2018) 10 SCC 443: Further discussed the misuse of Section 498A.

judgment.outcome: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal and laid down guidelines to prevent automatic arrests in cases registered under Section 498A IPC. The Court directed all state governments to instruct their police officers not to automatically arrest when a case under Section 498A IPC is registered but to first ascertain the necessity for arrest under Section 41 of the CrPC.
reasoning: The Court recognized the misuse of Section 498A IPC due to matrimonial disputes and the lack of proper investigation before arrests.
The Court emphasized the need to balance the rights of the complainant and the accused and to prevent unnecessary arrests.
The Court referred to Section 41 of the CrPC, which provides guidelines for arrest, and directed the police to follow these guidelines strictly before making any arrest under Section 498A IPC.
The Court considered the large number of pending cases under Section 498A IPC and the need to reduce the burden on the courts.
